forms.document_type: HIPAA Notice of Privacy Practices / compliance booklet (not an ROI form)

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: No downloadable records request form exists; patients must call or visit in person, or use MyChart for limited online access.

red_flags: No ROI form available online — patients must call or visit in person just to obtain the form, creating an unnecessary barrier to exercising HIPAA Right of Access
Internal ROI forms exist (referenced in chronic pain policy) but are not made publicly available to patients
bright_spots: Plain-language HIPAA notice following HHS model format — genuinely readable and well-structured
Comprehensive patient rights section covering dignity, comfort, and education
Filename convention suggests bilingual (English/Spanish) materials may be available
MyChart portal provides some digital access for established patients

findability.rationale: Level 1: Effectively unfindable online — despite exhaustive searching (web search, site crawl, sitemap, upload directory probing, Wayback Machine), no ROI or patient access request form exists on the website.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 1: No usable digital form exists — the only document found is a compliance booklet with zero fillable fields and no records request functionality.

content_design.rationale: Level 1: No records request form exists to evaluate; the compliance booklet's records access section says only 'Ask us how to do this,' which is unusable without outside help.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 2: Patient self-access is an afterthought — the HIPAA notice acknowledges the right but provides no actionable process; MyChart offers partial accommodation for established patients.

compliance.rationale: Level 2: The absence of any publicly available records request form creates an illegitimate barrier to HIPAA Right of Access; fee information is vague ('reasonable, cost-based fee' with no specifics).

overall.summary: El Rio Health does not publish any records request form online, forcing patients into an opaque phone/in-person process that fails to meet basic patient access expectations.
